content:
The town of Blackwood was quiet, nestled between thick forests and rolling hills. Life moved at a steady, predictable pace—until the stranger arrived.

It was late one evening when he appeared, stepping off a battered old carriage at the town square. Dressed in a long black coat, his face shadowed beneath a wide-brimmed hat, he carried only a small leather satchel. He said little, but his piercing green eyes seemed to study everything, as if he were looking for something—or someone.

Mrs. Henshaw, the town’s gossip, was the first to whisper about him. “He doesn’t belong here,” she told anyone who’d listen. “There’s something...unsettling about him.” Others agreed. The blacksmith swore he saw the stranger standing motionless by the old church for nearly an hour, and young Tommy Finch insisted he caught the man talking to himself in a language he didn’t recognize.

Despite the rumors, the stranger kept to himself, renting a small room at the inn. He rarely spoke, but when he did, his voice was deep and deliberate, as though each word had weight.
